Title.evidence: Biventricular Pacing After Cardiac Surgery: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to continuous biventricular pacing (n = 16) or standard of care (n = 18) using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment.

Participants.evidence: Conducted in a cardiac surgery unit, the trial included patients eligible based on risk of left ventricular dysfunction.

Intervention.evidence: The study aims to compare the efficacy of biventricular pacing versus atrial pacing.

Objective.evidence: The study aims to compare the efficacy of biventricular pacing versus atrial pacing.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was hemodynamic improvement, assessed by cardiac output and vasoactive-inotropic score, over the first 24 hours post-bypass.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomised to continuous biventricular pacing (n = 16) or standard of care (n = 18) using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants were randomised to continuous biventricular pacing (n = 16) or standard of care (n = 18).

Number_Analysed.evidence: Thirty-four patients were randomised and analysed.

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 12 to 24 hours post-bypass, the paced group exhibited a lower intrinsic heart rate (76.5 ± 17.5 vs 91.7 ± 13.0 beats per minute; P = .040).

Trial_Registration.evidence: Trial registration and funding information were not provided.

Funding.evidence: Trial registration and funding information were not provided.
